title: Belfast shipyard that built the Titanic rescued by an AIM-listed firm
text:
The Belfast shipyard that built the Titanic has been rescued by an AIM-listed energy infrastructure firm.

Infrastrata has agreed to pay £6million for Harland And Wolff, which went into administration in August following the collapse of its Norwegian parent group.

The deal will save the jobs of the 79 staff who did not opt for voluntary redundancy – and Infrastrata is aiming to have 400 employees at the yard by 2025.

The Titanic, left, and its sister ship the Olympic, right, are pictured at the Harland And Wolff shipyard in Northern Ireland in 1912

It had 35,000 workers during the Second World War, and between 1909 and 1914 built the Titanic, the Olympic and Britannic.

The shipyard, whose two yellow cranes, Samson and Goliath, are part of the Belfast skyline, has also built oil platforms and wind turbines.

Infrastrata will use it to build the metal fabrication for its huge underground gas storage facility in Northern Ireland, in Islandmagee.

Chief executive John Wood said it was a 'natural fit' and that it had been eyeing local opportunities for the fabrication work for around a year.

He added: 'We liked the concept of Harland And Wolff and then, when it became available, we certainly got involved very quickly.'

But the shipyard will also be '100 per cent open to any approaches' for defence, shipbuilding or other contracts.
